awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: IGE: Scaling Faculty Development to Broaden Participation in Graduate Education
awd_abstract_narration:
This National Science Foundation Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) award to the University of Southern California and Rochester Institute of Technology will pilot a network of faculty and administrators across six major California universities that aims to improve how universities choose the scientists of the future. Currently, the demographic composition of the student body in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) doctoral programs and the scientific workforce is not only different from the composition of U.S. demographics, but it is also changing more slowly than the demographic shifts in the US. It is important to address these inequities in order to create a robust domestic scientific workforce, which may contribute to a healthy economy and promote U.S. scientific superiority. Inherited practices for recruiting, admitting, and mentoring graduate students contribute to these inequities, as does the lack of opportunity for faculty to reflect upon their practices in these areas. This award creates innovative systems by which faculty can improve those practices, and therefore holds significant promise as a strategy for broadening participation in graduate education and the scientific workforce. 

The project will form a network that provides faculty and graduate school administrators within and across the University of Southern California and University of California campuses at Berkeley, Davis, Irvine, Los Angeles, and Santa Barbara with opportunity and incentives to critically reflect upon and change longstanding practices. Participating STEM PhD programs will receive professional development from project leaders in the form of workshops and continuous learning activities on recruiting, admitting, and mentoring graduate students from diverse backgrounds. Leaders that emerge from each program in years 1 and 2 will be selected to establish campus-level teams who will deliver similar faculty-to-faculty learning opportunities on their own campuses. The research and evaluation activities of the project involve a sequential multi-method study, including the first-ever clustered randomized experiment to test the impact of faculty development around three outcomes: the admissions practices that PhD programs use, the diversity of their admitted cohorts, and the programs' selectivity. The structure of the network allows for sustainable gains, and it works with, rather than against, the decentralized nature of graduate education and its varied institutional and disciplinary contexts. 

The Innovations in Graduate Education (IGE) program is focused on research in graduate education. The goals of IGE are to pilot, test and validate innovative approaches to graduate education and to generate the knowledge required to move these approaches into the broader community.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Collaborative Research: IGE: Scaling Faculty Development to Broaden Participation in Graduate Education 

The demographic composition of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) doctoral programs and the scientific workforce is not only different from the US population, but it is also changing more slowly than demographic shifts in the US. To create a robust domestic scientific workforce, it is important to address these inequities. Inherited mindsets and methods for recruiting, admitting, and mentoring graduate students are root causes of disproportionate exclusion of Black, Latinx, Indigenous people, and women of all backgrounds, as is the lack of opportunity for faculty to reflect upon and change their practices in these areas.

A growing body of social science research holds potential to improve how we select and serve PhD students. This project scaled up research-based faculty professional development curriculum and piloted a network of faculty and administrators across six California universities. The California Consortium for Inclusive Doctoral Education (C-CIDE) brought together change-ready graduate schools, PhD programs, and leaders within them. Its guiding vision was to build capacity to equitably select and serve PhD students from historically underrepresented racial/ethnic and gender backgrounds. We scaled up existing graduate admissions and recruitment workshops designed for physics departments under former NSF awards to different disciplinary and institutional contexts. We offered 75 workshops over the course of the project as a whole and, as a means of sustainability, trained more than 25 facilitators to lead workshops in equity-minded admissions and mentoring at partner universities beyond the award period.  

External evaluation using rigorous quantitative methods showed that our partners changed their admissions and recruitment practices after participating in C-CIDE workshops, and that they significantly increased the diversity and selectivity of applicants, admitted students, and enrollees. For example, most programs eliminated GRE score requirements for admission. There was also evidence of increases in admissions committees meeting to discuss criteria before file review, revisiting their admissions practices, conducting more careful reading of transcripts, and encouraging reviewers to consider applicant potential rather than just achievements. The evaluation also found statistically significant increases in the number of applications, admitted students, and enrollees from racially minoritized groups each year from 2018 through 2021. We found some evidence of increases in applicants and admits who are women post-workshop, but these changes tended to be delayed. We did not find statistically significant changes in the number of women enrolled in participating programs in post-workshop years. 

In addition to scaling up these workshops as a space for reflection, discussion, and initiating change, an important outcome was the creation of a learning community inspired by the Networked Improvement Community model. The partner universities included the graduate schools (or equivalent) of UC San Diego, UC Berkeley, UC Davis, UC Santa Barbara, UC Irvine, and University of Southern California. The PhD program partners represented the following fields of study: engineering; natural resources; environmental science and policy/management; mathematics; physical sciences; biology; neuroscience; psychology; and computer science. We purposefully developed and advanced with this group a model of equity-minded holistic admissions that complies with California?s and other states? bans on affirmative action in admissions.

Critical to C-CIDE were specific individuals or dyads within our partner graduate schools who served as campus liaisons to the project. These individuals coordinated campus-level activities and leveraged their knowledge of local needs and resources to support positive changes in partner graduate programs and the wider universities they served. Campus liaisons met regularly as a group with project leaders, and an external assessment found that liaisons experienced these meetings and community as a site of leadership development. Campus liaisons and other leaders also interacted with the consortium through local workshops, consortium-wide meetings, trainings, a quarterly virtual journal club that we sponsored, and one-on-one connections with other project leaders and change agents.

Social science research conducted by the project looked into what helped and hindered the implementation of holistic admissions amongst faculty in the consortium?s partner graduate programs. The data reveal change is multilevel, involving new structural, cultural, and cognitive admissions routines, which carry promise for disrupting institutionalized inequities where the politics of changing these routines can be managed. Specifically, we found that the transition to holistic review involves undermining previously unquestioned evaluation routines and protecting the possibility of new routines by managing the dialogue around change.  Barriers to change included inconsistent support of departmental and university leadership, the decentralized nature of graduate admissions (i.e., a lack of central oversight), and limited staffing support. 

Broader impacts of this project include national scaling and sustainability via a network of 13 research universities (the Equity in Graduate Education Consortium); contribution to several national and international initiatives around equity, inclusion, and systemic change in STEM and doctoral education; as well as replication of the C-CIDE model by a group of universities in the United Kingdom (the Yorkshire Consortium for Equity in Doctoral Education).
